description: From Ancient Greek Φιλιππίζειν (Philippízein), from Φίλιππος (Phílippos), the name of Philip II of Macedon.

verbs.description: philippize (third-person singular simple present philippizes, present participle philippizing, simple past and past participle philippized)

entries.meaning: (now rare, historical) To support or advocate the cause of Philip of Macedon; (more generally) to speak as someone who has been wrongly inspired or corrupted. [from 16th c.]
examples: I know they set him up as a sort of oracle; because, with the best intentions in the world, he naturally philippizes, and chaunts his prophetic song in exact unison with their designs.

verbs.description: philippize (third-person singular simple present philippizes, present participle philippizing, simple past and past participle philippized)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To write or speak in the style of a philippic; to rant. [19th c.]
examples: I feel tempted, just here, to philippize the press. It needs castigation, but this will never prove effective, because a portion of the evil lies in the popular appetite.
